channel.title: Recommend me some books
channel.description: It's been awhile since I've actually sat down and read a book, recommend me some books. Anything you found that was really good to read tell me the name. Not really sure what I'll like, but shoot out some suggestions.

item.title: Recommend me some books
item.dc:creator: @Elrick Elrick
item.description:
@Elrick wrote:

Kite Runner and Farenheit were also assigned to be read for my high school English courses :P. I loved Farenheit though, a lot of good morals to take away from that and really makes you think.

Read full topic

item.title: Recommend me some books
item.dc:creator: @reyx7 reyx7
item.description:
@reyx7 wrote:

[quote=“Elrick, post:22, topic:525641”][quote author=reyx7 link=topic=644381.msg4336026#msg4336026 date=1374382948]
Are you looking for just general classics? Some of my favorite books are…

1984 - George Orwell -> Favorite dystopian novel with a great love story, a classic indeed
Animal Farm - George Orwell -> another dystopian novel, just generally well written
Watership Down - Richard Adams -> it seems odd, but trust me it’s a great book.
Slaughterhouse Five - Kurt Vonnegut -> Vonnegut has a great, sophisticated sense of humor. Some like it, some don’t.
The Great Gatsby - Larry Fitzgerald -> READ BOOK, THEN MOVIE. If you’ve seen the movie, you’ll get a weird perception of the book.
The Count of Monte Cristo - Alexandre Dumas -> Although written in the 19th century, it was in French, therefor when it was translated it was put into modern English. An amazing story, just an epic read. 200 pages in of the roughly 900 and I was hooked.
The Catcher in the Rye - JD Stalinger -> Another one that goes both ways. Some see it as a kid complaining for 300 pages, others really take the message in and relate to it.
Fahrenheit 451 - Ray Bradbury -> Another dystopian novel. I really like dystopian novels…
Catch-22 - Joseph Heller -> Wasn’t my favorite, but it’s where the phrase comes from. A decent novel non the less
The Giver - Lois Lowry -> She does a lot of dystopian novels as well, this one, however, is the best
The Kite Runner - Khaled Hosseini -> Seriously the saddest fudgeing book I’ve ever read. It gets worse and worse and worse and you just feel like you’re worthless. Manly fudgeing tears dude, manly fudgeing tears

That list should keep you busy. Enjoy!
[/quote]
You either just graduated from Highschool or you’re a teacher. :P[/quote]
I only read 1984, watership, gatsby, catcher, and the giver in HS. The rest I’ve just been recommended and greatly enjoyed.

Read full topic

1984 - George Orwell -> Favorite dystopian novel with a great love story, a classic indeed

Watership Down - Richard Adams -> it seems odd, but trust me it’s a great book.
Slaughterhouse Five - Kurt Vonnegut -> Vonnegut has a great, sophisticated sense of humor. Some like it, some don’t.
The Great Gatsby - Larry Fitzgerald -> READ BOOK, THEN MOVIE. If you’ve seen the movie, you’ll get a weird perception of the book.
The Count of Monte Cristo - Alexandre Dumas -> Although written in the 19th century, it was in French, therefor when it was translated it was put into modern English. An amazing story, just an epic read. 200 pages in of the roughly 900 and I was hooked.
The Catcher in the Rye - JD Stalinger -> Another one that goes both ways. Some see it as a kid complaining for 300 pages, others really take the message in and relate to it.
Fahrenheit 451 - Ray Bradbury -> Another dystopian novel. I really like dystopian novels…
Catch-22 - Joseph Heller -> Wasn’t my favorite, but it’s where the phrase comes from. A decent novel non the less
The Giver - Lois Lowry -> She does a lot of dystopian novels as well, this one, however, is the best
The Kite Runner - Khaled Hosseini -> Seriously the saddest fudgeing book I’ve ever read. It gets worse and worse and worse and you just feel like you’re worthless. Manly fudgeing tears dude, manly fudgeing tears

That list should keep you busy. Enjoy![/quote]
You either just graduated from Highschool or you’re a teacher.

item.title: Recommend me some books
item.dc:creator: @krackkid Krackkid
item.description:
@krackkid wrote:

Fifty Shades of Grey

en.wikipedia.org

Fifty Shades of Grey

Fifty Shades of Grey is a 2011 erotic romance novel by British author E. L. James, originally a Twilight fan fiction with Christian Grey as a non-vampire Edward Cullen and Anastasia Steele as a pale, gamine Bella Swan. It is the first instalment in the Fifty Shades trilogy that traces the deepening relationship between a college graduate, Anastasia Steele, and a young business magnate, Christian Grey. It is notable for its explicitly erotic scenes featuring elements of sexual practices involvi Fi...

Great book

Read full topic

item.title: Recommend me some books
item.dc:creator: @vManlyMan vManlyMan
item.description:
@vManlyMan wrote:

en.wikipedia.org

The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy

The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy (sometimes referred to as HG2G, HHGTTG or H2G2) is a comedy science fiction series created by Douglas Adams. Originally a radio comedy broadcast on BBC Radio 4 in 1978, it was later adapted to other formats, including stage shows, novels, comic books, a 1981 TV series, a 1984 video game, and 2005 feature film. A prominent series in British popular culture, The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy has become an international multi-media phenomenon; the novels are t...

Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy by Douglas Adams is a neat book

Read full topic
